units.title: Ecosystems & Habitats
units.description: Explore how living things interact with each other and their environment in different habitats around the world.

content.explanation: An ecosystem is a community of living things (plants, animals, insects, and microorganisms) that interact with each other and their non-living environment (water, soil, sunlight, air, and temperature). Think of it like a neighborhood where everyone depends on each other. In a pond ecosystem, fish eat insects, frogs eat flies, and plants make oxygen that the animals breathe. Every part of an ecosystem has an important job. If one part changes, it can affect everything else. For example, if all the plants in a pond died, the animals that eat plants would have no food, and the animals that eat those animals would also go hungry.

examples.problem: What are the living parts of a forest ecosystem?
examples.answer: Trees, birds, squirrels, insects, mushrooms, deer, and other plants and animals.
examples.explanation: Living things in an ecosystem are called biotic factors. They include all plants, animals, fungi, and tiny organisms.

examples.problem: What are the non-living parts of a forest ecosystem?
examples.answer: Sunlight, water, soil, air, rocks, and temperature.
examples.explanation: Non-living things in an ecosystem are called abiotic factors. They provide the conditions that living things need to survive.

content.real_world: Your backyard is a small ecosystem! The grass, flowers, insects, birds, worms, soil, water, and sunlight all work together as a system.

practice_problems.hint: An ecosystem includes many living and non-living things working together.

content.explanation: A habitat is the natural home or environment where a plant or animal lives. Different habitats provide different conditions like temperature, water, food, and shelter. There are many types of habitats on Earth, including forests, deserts, oceans, grasslands, wetlands, and tundra. Each habitat has special conditions that certain plants and animals have adapted to live in. A cactus is perfectly suited for a hot, dry desert, but it would not survive in a cold tundra. A polar bear needs cold, icy conditions and would overheat in a tropical forest. Animals and plants have special features called adaptations that help them survive in their specific habitat.

examples.problem: Why can a camel survive in the desert?
examples.answer: Camels have humps that store fat for energy, wide feet for walking on sand, and can go a long time without water.
examples.explanation: These are adaptations — special features that help camels survive in their hot, dry desert habitat.

examples.problem: Name three different habitats.
examples.answer: Forest, ocean, and desert.
examples.explanation: Each habitat has different temperatures, amounts of water, and types of food available for plants and animals.

content.real_world: Even in your town, there are small habitats — a bird's nest in a tree, a worm's burrow in the soil, or a spider's web in a corner of your house!

content.explanation: A food chain shows how energy passes from one living thing to another through food. Every food chain starts with the sun, which provides energy for plants. Plants use sunlight to make their own food through a process called photosynthesis, so they are called producers. Animals that eat plants are called herbivores or primary consumers. Animals that eat other animals are called carnivores or secondary consumers. Animals that eat both plants and animals are called omnivores. When living things die, decomposers like mushrooms and bacteria break them down and return nutrients to the soil. An example of a simple food chain is: sun → grass → rabbit → fox.

examples.problem: In the food chain: sun → corn → mouse → owl, what is the producer?
examples.answer: Corn is the producer.
examples.explanation: Corn is a plant that uses sunlight to make its own food. Producers are always plants or algae at the start of a food chain.

examples.problem: What role does a rabbit play in a food chain?
examples.answer: A rabbit is a primary consumer (herbivore).
examples.explanation: Rabbits eat plants like grass and clover, making them herbivores and primary consumers in the food chain.

content.real_world: When you eat a salad, you are a primary consumer eating producers (lettuce, tomatoes). When you eat a chicken sandwich, you are a secondary consumer eating a consumer (chicken) that ate producers (grain).

practice_problems.hint: Food chains always start with the energy source and the organisms that make their own food.

practice_problems.hint: Producers make their own food. Does a fox make its own food or eat other animals?

practice_problems.hint: Plants use a process called photosynthesis to convert sunlight into food.

practice_problems.hint: The prefix 'omni-' means 'all.' This type of animal eats all kinds of food.

lessons.title: How Living Things Depend on Each Other

content.explanation: In an ecosystem, living things depend on each other in many ways. Some animals depend on plants for food and shelter. Bees depend on flowers for nectar, and flowers depend on bees for pollination (spreading pollen so new plants can grow). This is called a symbiotic relationship — both organisms benefit. Some animals depend on other animals. Birds called oxpeckers sit on the backs of buffalo and eat ticks and bugs off their skin. The oxpecker gets food, and the buffalo gets cleaned! When one species in an ecosystem disappears, it creates a chain reaction. If all the bees disappeared, many plants could not reproduce, which would mean less food for herbivores, and then less food for carnivores too.

examples.problem: How do bees and flowers help each other?
examples.answer: Bees get nectar from flowers for food, and they spread pollen between flowers which helps plants reproduce.
examples.explanation: This is a win-win relationship where both living things benefit from each other.

examples.problem: What might happen if all the frogs in a pond ecosystem disappeared?
examples.answer: The insect population would grow because frogs eat insects. More insects might eat more plants. Animals that eat frogs, like snakes, would lose a food source.
examples.explanation: Removing one species from an ecosystem affects many other species because everything is connected.

content.real_world: Farmers often put beehives near their crops because bees help pollinate the plants, which makes the crops produce more fruit and vegetables.

options: When pollen is moved from one flower to another to help plants reproduce
practice_problems.hint: This process involves spreading something that helps flowers make seeds.

practice_problems.hint: Think about what happens to the food chain when one link is removed.

practice_problems.hint: Wolves are predators that eat deer. Without predators, what happens to the prey population?

content.explanation: Ecosystems around the world are being damaged by human activities. Pollution from factories and cars can poison water and air, harming plants and animals. Cutting down forests (deforestation) destroys the habitat of countless species. Littering can injure or kill animals who eat or get tangled in trash. Climate change is making some habitats too warm or too dry for the species living there. But there is good news — people can help protect ecosystems! We can reduce, reuse, and recycle to create less waste. We can plant trees and create gardens to provide habitats. National parks and wildlife reserves protect large areas of natural habitat. Even small actions like picking up litter, using less water, and learning about local wildlife can make a big difference.

examples.problem: How does littering hurt ecosystems?
examples.answer: Animals can eat litter and get sick, get tangled in plastic, and trash can pollute water sources.
examples.explanation: Every piece of litter in nature can potentially harm wildlife. Plastic bags in the ocean look like jellyfish to sea turtles, who eat them and get sick.

examples.problem: Name two ways you can help protect an ecosystem.
examples.answer: Pick up litter and plant native flowers or trees.
examples.explanation: Picking up litter keeps animals safe, and planting native plants provides food and shelter for local wildlife like birds and butterflies.

content.real_world: Many schools have started gardens to help local pollinators like bees and butterflies. Even a small garden with native flowers can provide an important habitat for these helpful insects.

units.title: Life Cycles
units.description: Learn how different living things grow, change, and reproduce throughout their lives, including butterflies, frogs, and plants.

content.explanation: A life cycle is the series of stages a living thing goes through from the beginning of its life until it produces offspring (babies) and the cycle starts again. Every living thing — plants, animals, insects, and even humans — has a life cycle. Some life cycles are simple, with babies looking like small versions of the adults (like cats and dogs). Other life cycles involve dramatic changes where the young look completely different from the adults (like butterflies and frogs). The stages of a life cycle always happen in the same order, and the cycle repeats generation after generation. Understanding life cycles helps us learn about how living things grow, change, and continue their species.

examples.problem: What is the life cycle of a human?
examples.answer: Baby → child → teenager → adult → parent (has babies, and the cycle repeats).
examples.explanation: Humans have a life cycle where they gradually grow bigger and more mature, but they always look like humans at every stage.

examples.problem: Do all animals have the same life cycle?
examples.answer: No, different animals have different life cycles. Some change form dramatically (like butterflies), while others just grow bigger (like dogs).
examples.explanation: The variety of life cycles in nature is amazing. Some animals go through complete transformations called metamorphosis.

content.real_world: You are living your own life cycle right now! You started as a baby, grew into a child, and will eventually become a teenager and then an adult.

practice_problems.hint: Think about the different stages a living thing goes through as it grows.

practice_problems.hint: The word 'cycle' means something that goes around and repeats.

practice_problems.hint: This word describes the new generation that an animal produces.

content.explanation: The butterfly has one of the most amazing life cycles in nature. It goes through four stages in a process called complete metamorphosis. First, an adult butterfly lays tiny eggs on a leaf. Second, a caterpillar (also called a larva) hatches from the egg. The caterpillar eats leaves constantly and grows much bigger, shedding its skin several times as it grows. Third, the caterpillar forms a chrysalis (also called a pupa) around itself. Inside the chrysalis, the caterpillar's body completely transforms — this stage can last from a few weeks to several months. Fourth, a beautiful adult butterfly emerges from the chrysalis with wings! The adult butterfly drinks nectar from flowers, mates, lays eggs, and the cycle starts all over again.

examples.problem: What are the four stages of a butterfly's life cycle?
examples.answer: Egg → Larva (caterpillar) → Pupa (chrysalis) → Adult butterfly
examples.explanation: Each stage looks completely different. The caterpillar has no wings and crawls, while the adult butterfly has wings and flies!

examples.problem: What happens inside the chrysalis?
examples.answer: The caterpillar's body breaks down and completely transforms into a butterfly.
examples.explanation: Inside the chrysalis, special cells reorganize the caterpillar's body, forming wings, antennae, and a completely new body shape.

content.real_world: Monarch butterflies travel thousands of miles during migration. The butterflies that fly south in fall are the great-great-grandchildren of the ones that flew north in spring — four generations in one year!

practice_problems.question: What is the correct order of a butterfly's life cycle?

practice_problems.question: The caterpillar stage of a butterfly's life cycle is also called the ___ stage.
practice_problems.hint: This scientific word is used for the young feeding stage of insects that undergo metamorphosis.

content.explanation: Frogs also go through metamorphosis, but their life cycle is different from butterflies. A frog's life cycle has several stages. First, an adult frog lays eggs (called frogspawn) in water. The eggs are surrounded by a jelly-like substance that protects them. After about one to three weeks, tadpoles hatch from the eggs. Tadpoles look like small fish — they have tails, no legs, and breathe through gills underwater. Over several weeks, the tadpole begins to change. It grows back legs first, then front legs. Its tail gets shorter and shorter. Its gills are replaced by lungs so it can breathe air. Finally, the tadpole has fully transformed into a young frog (called a froglet) and can leave the water to live on land. The adult frog can live both in water and on land.

examples.problem: How is a tadpole different from an adult frog?
examples.answer: A tadpole has a tail, no legs, and gills for breathing underwater. An adult frog has four legs, no tail, and lungs for breathing air.
examples.explanation: Tadpoles are adapted for life underwater, while adult frogs can live on both land and water.

examples.problem: Where does a frog lay its eggs?
examples.answer: In water, usually in ponds, lakes, or slow-moving streams.
examples.explanation: Frog eggs and tadpoles need water to survive. The eggs are surrounded by a jelly coating that keeps them moist.

content.real_world: Frogs are amphibians, which means 'double life' — they live part of their life in water and part on land. If you visit a pond in spring, you might see frogspawn (clusters of eggs) near the edges of the water.

practice_problems.hint: It is like a 'mini' frog — add a suffix to the word 'frog.'

content.explanation: Plants have life cycles too! A flowering plant's life cycle begins with a seed. When a seed gets the right amount of water, warmth, and sometimes light, it begins to germinate (sprout). A tiny root grows down into the soil, and a small stem pushes up toward the light. This young plant is called a seedling. As the seedling gets water, nutrients from the soil, and sunlight, it grows into a mature plant with a strong stem, leaves, and roots. The mature plant produces flowers. Flowers contain special parts for reproduction: the stamen makes pollen, and the pistil contains ovules. When pollen reaches the pistil (through pollination by wind, insects, or animals), seeds form inside the flower. The seeds are often found inside fruit. When the seeds are spread to new places (by wind, animals, or water), they can germinate and grow into new plants, starting the cycle again.

examples.problem: What does a seed need to germinate?
examples.answer: A seed needs water, warmth, and sometimes light to begin growing.
examples.explanation: Germination is the process of a seed sprouting. The seed absorbs water, the seed coat softens, and the tiny plant inside begins to grow.

examples.problem: How do seeds get spread to new places?
examples.answer: Seeds can be spread by wind (dandelions), animals (berries eaten by birds), water (coconuts floating), or even by sticking to fur or clothing.
examples.explanation: Seed dispersal is important because new plants need space, light, and nutrients to grow — they can't all grow in the same spot.

content.real_world: When you eat an apple, you are eating the fruit of an apple tree. The seeds inside the apple could grow into new apple trees if planted in soil!

practice_problems.hint: Think about dandelion fluff blowing in the wind or berries being eaten by birds.

practice_problems.hint: It is a small 'baby' plant. Think of 'seed' plus a suffix.

content.explanation: Now that we have learned about different life cycles, let's compare them! Butterflies and frogs both go through metamorphosis — dramatic changes in body form — but their stages are different. Butterflies have four stages (egg, larva, pupa, adult) while frogs also have stages but change more gradually (egg, tadpole, froglet, adult frog). Some animals, like dogs and cats, have simpler life cycles without metamorphosis — the babies look like miniature adults and just grow bigger. Plants have their own unique life cycle involving seeds, germination, growth, flowering, and seed production. One thing ALL life cycles have in common is that they are cycles — they repeat. The adult organism produces offspring, and the offspring go through the same stages. This is how species continue to exist generation after generation.

examples.problem: How are the butterfly and frog life cycles similar?
examples.answer: Both start as eggs, go through metamorphosis (dramatic body changes), and end as adults that look very different from their young form.
examples.explanation: Both butterflies and frogs undergo amazing transformations. However, a caterpillar changes inside a chrysalis, while a tadpole changes gradually in the water.

examples.answer: A puppy looks like a small dog and just grows bigger. A caterpillar looks nothing like an adult butterfly and must go through metamorphosis.
examples.explanation: Dogs do not go through metamorphosis. They have a simpler life cycle: birth → puppy → adult dog → parent.

content.real_world: Scientists who study life cycles are called biologists. By understanding how animals grow and reproduce, scientists can help protect endangered species and their habitats.

units.title: States of Matter
units.description: Discover the three main states of matter — solid, liquid, and gas — and learn how matter can change from one state to another.

content.explanation: Everything around you is made of matter. Matter is anything that takes up space and has mass (weight). Your desk, your pencil, the air you breathe, and even the water you drink are all made of matter. Matter is made up of tiny particles called atoms and molecules that are too small to see. These tiny particles are always moving! In different states of matter, the particles move and behave differently. There are three main states of matter: solids, liquids, and gases. The state of matter depends on how much energy the particles have and how tightly they are packed together. When matter has a little energy, the particles are tightly packed and barely move — that is a solid. When it has more energy, the particles slide past each other — that is a liquid. With a lot of energy, the particles spread far apart and move very fast — that is a gas.

examples.problem: Is air matter?
examples.answer: Yes! Air is matter because it takes up space (fill a balloon to see) and has mass (a balloon full of air weighs more than an empty one).
examples.explanation: Even though we cannot see air, it is still made of tiny particles (molecules of nitrogen, oxygen, and other gases) that take up space.

examples.problem: Name one example each of a solid, liquid, and gas.
examples.answer: Solid: rock. Liquid: water. Gas: oxygen in the air.
examples.explanation: Matter can exist in any of these three states depending on temperature and pressure.

content.real_world: You interact with all three states of matter every day — you walk on solid ground, drink liquid water, and breathe gaseous air!

practice_problems.hint: Remember, matter includes things you can see AND things you cannot see, like air.

practice_problems.question: Which of these is NOT matter?
practice_problems.hint: Matter has mass and takes up space. Which one of these does not have mass or take up space?

content.explanation: Solids are one of the three main states of matter. In a solid, the particles are packed closely together and vibrate in place but do not move around freely. This is why solids have a definite shape and a definite volume (they take up a specific amount of space). A rock does not change shape when you put it in a bowl — it stays the same shape. Solids can be hard like metal or soft like a pillow. They can be rough like sandpaper or smooth like glass. They can be flexible like rubber or rigid like wood. But no matter what, they keep their shape unless a force is applied to change it (like breaking, cutting, or bending). Some solids are made of crystals with particles arranged in neat patterns, like salt and diamonds.

examples.problem: Why does an ice cube keep its shape?
examples.answer: An ice cube is a solid. Its particles are tightly packed and locked in place, so it holds its shape.
examples.explanation: The water molecules in ice are arranged in a fixed pattern, giving the ice cube its rigid shape.

examples.problem: Name five examples of solids.
examples.answer: Wood, rock, ice, metal, and plastic.
examples.explanation: All of these have a definite shape and volume because their particles are tightly packed together.

content.real_world: The chair you sit in, the shoes on your feet, and the building you live in are all made of solids. Without solids, we could not build anything!

content.explanation: Liquids are the second state of matter. In a liquid, the particles are close together but not locked in place — they can slide past each other. This is why liquids can flow and take the shape of whatever container they are in. Pour water into a round bowl, and it takes the shape of the bowl. Pour the same water into a square box, and it takes the shape of the box. However, a liquid does have a definite volume — a cup of water is always a cup of water whether it is in a tall glass or a flat plate. Liquids can be thin and runny like water, or thick and slow like honey or syrup. Some liquids are clear like water, while others are opaque like milk. All liquids can be poured, and they always flow to the lowest point because of gravity.

examples.problem: Why does water take the shape of its container?
examples.answer: Water is a liquid. Its particles can slide past each other, so the liquid flows and takes the shape of whatever container holds it.
examples.explanation: Unlike a solid where particles are locked in place, liquid particles are free to move around each other.

examples.problem: Does a liquid have a definite volume?
examples.answer: Yes! One cup of water is always one cup of water, even if you pour it into different shaped containers.
examples.explanation: Liquids change shape but not volume. The amount of liquid stays the same.

content.real_world: When you pour juice into a glass, it takes the shape of the glass. If you spill it, it flows across the table and drips to the floor — because liquids always flow to the lowest point.

content.explanation: Gases are the third state of matter. In a gas, the particles have lots of energy and move very fast in all directions. They spread out to fill whatever space is available. Unlike solids and liquids, gases have no definite shape AND no definite volume — they expand to fill their entire container. This is why the air in a room fills the whole room, and the air in a balloon fills the whole balloon. You cannot usually see gases, but you can often feel them (like wind) or smell them (like the smell of cookies baking). When you blow up a balloon, you are trapping gas (air) inside. The gas pushes against the walls of the balloon in all directions, which is why balloons are puffy. If you pop the balloon, the gas rushes out and spreads into the room.

examples.problem: Why can you smell cookies baking from another room?
examples.answer: The smell is carried by gas molecules that spread through the air from the kitchen to wherever you are.
examples.explanation: Gas particles move freely and spread out in all directions, carrying the scent molecules throughout the house.

examples.problem: Does a gas have a definite shape or volume?
examples.answer: No. A gas has no definite shape and no definite volume. It expands to fill whatever container or space it is in.
examples.explanation: Gas particles are far apart and move freely, so they spread out to fill any available space.

content.real_world: When you pump air into a bicycle tire, you are forcing gas into a small space. The gas pushes outward on the tire, making it firm enough to ride on.

content.explanation: Matter can change from one state to another when energy (usually heat) is added or removed. When you heat a solid, the particles gain energy and start moving more. If you add enough heat, the solid melts and becomes a liquid. This is called melting. The temperature at which a solid melts is called its melting point — ice melts at 32°F (0°C). When you heat a liquid even more, the particles gain even more energy and escape into the air. The liquid evaporates and becomes a gas. Water boils and turns into steam at 212°F (100°C). The opposite also happens: when you cool a gas, it condenses back into a liquid. When you cool a liquid, it freezes and becomes a solid again. Think of water: ice (solid) → water (liquid) → steam (gas), and it can change back and forth!

examples.problem: What happens to an ice cube when you leave it on a warm counter?
examples.answer: It melts and turns from a solid into a liquid (water).
examples.explanation: The heat from the warm air gives the ice particles more energy. They start moving more freely and the ice turns into liquid water. This is called melting.

examples.problem: What happens to water in a pot on a hot stove?
examples.answer: The water heats up and eventually boils, turning into steam (gas). This is called evaporation or boiling.
examples.explanation: As heat is added, the water particles gain energy and move faster. At 212°F (100°C), they have enough energy to escape into the air as water vapor.

content.real_world: You see states of matter change every day! Ice cream melts on a hot day (solid to liquid). Puddles dry up in the sun (liquid to gas). Dew forms on grass in the morning (gas to liquid). Water freezes into ice cubes in the freezer (liquid to solid).

units.title: The Water Cycle
units.description: Follow water on its amazing journey through the water cycle, from evaporation to condensation to precipitation and back again.

content.explanation: The water cycle is the continuous journey that water takes through the environment. Water on Earth is constantly moving and changing form — it goes from oceans, lakes, and rivers into the air, forms clouds, falls back to the ground as rain or snow, and flows back to the oceans. This cycle has been happening for billions of years! The same water that exists on Earth today is the same water that dinosaurs drank millions of years ago. Water is never created or destroyed — it just keeps recycling. The water cycle is powered by the sun's energy, which heats water and causes it to evaporate. Gravity also plays a role by pulling water back down to Earth as precipitation and causing rivers to flow downhill to the ocean.

examples.problem: What powers the water cycle?
examples.answer: The sun's energy powers the water cycle by heating water and causing it to evaporate.
examples.explanation: Without the sun, water would not evaporate into the air, clouds would not form, and rain would not fall. The sun is the engine of the water cycle.

examples.problem: Is new water being made on Earth?
examples.answer: No! The water on Earth today is the same water that has always been here. It just keeps cycling through different forms and locations.
examples.explanation: Water is a renewable resource because it is constantly recycled through the water cycle.

content.real_world: The water you drink today might have once been in a cloud, a river, an ocean, or even a glass of water a dinosaur drank millions of years ago!

options: A type of bicycle made of water

practice_problems.hint: Think about how water moves from oceans to sky to land and back again.

content.explanation: Evaporation is the first main step of the water cycle. It happens when the sun heats water in oceans, lakes, rivers, and puddles. The heat gives the water particles enough energy to escape from the liquid and rise into the air as an invisible gas called water vapor. You cannot see water vapor, but it is all around you in the air. Evaporation happens faster when the temperature is higher, when the air is dry, and when there is wind. That is why puddles dry up faster on a hot, sunny, windy day than on a cool, cloudy, still day. Evaporation does not only happen from bodies of water — plants also release water vapor from their leaves through a process called transpiration. Animals release water vapor when they breathe out.

examples.problem: Why do puddles disappear on a sunny day?
examples.answer: The sun heats the water in the puddle. The water evaporates — it turns into water vapor and rises into the air.
examples.explanation: The water is not really 'gone' — it has changed from liquid water to invisible water vapor in the air.

examples.problem: Can you see water vapor?
examples.answer: No, water vapor is an invisible gas. The steam you see above a boiling pot is actually tiny water droplets, not water vapor.
examples.explanation: True water vapor is invisible. What we call 'steam' that we can see is actually tiny droplets of liquid water floating in the air.

content.real_world: When your wet hair dries after a shower, that is evaporation! The water in your hair absorbs heat and turns into water vapor that floats away into the air.

practice_problems.hint: This process changes liquid water into a gas that rises into the air.

practice_problems.hint: This is the invisible gas form of water in the air.

practice_problems.hint: More heat means more energy for water particles to escape into the air.

practice_problems.hint: What gives water particles enough energy to escape into the air?

practice_problems.hint: This word is specifically used for water vapor released by plants.

content.explanation: After water evaporates and rises into the sky as water vapor, it eventually cools down. When water vapor cools enough, it changes back into tiny droplets of liquid water. This process is called condensation. High in the sky, water vapor condenses onto tiny particles of dust, pollen, or pollution in the air. Billions of these tiny water droplets group together to form clouds. Clouds come in many shapes and sizes. Fluffy white cumulus clouds usually mean fair weather. Thin, wispy cirrus clouds are very high in the sky. Dark, flat stratus clouds often bring steady rain. Tall, towering cumulonimbus clouds bring thunderstorms. You can see condensation happening on Earth too — when you breathe out on a cold day, your warm breath meets cold air and the water vapor condenses into a little cloud you can see!

examples.problem: Why do water droplets form on the outside of a cold glass on a warm day?
examples.answer: Water vapor in the warm air touches the cold glass and condenses into liquid water droplets on the surface.
examples.explanation: This is condensation — when warm, moist air meets a cold surface, the water vapor cools down and turns back into liquid water.

examples.problem: How do clouds form?
examples.answer: Water vapor rises into the sky, cools down, and condenses into tiny water droplets that cling to dust particles. Billions of these droplets together form a cloud.
examples.explanation: Clouds are actually made of tiny liquid water droplets (or ice crystals) floating in the air.

content.real_world: On a cold morning, you can see condensation on car windows and on the grass (dew). The warm air cooled overnight, and the water vapor condensed into tiny droplets.

content.explanation: Precipitation is water falling from clouds back to Earth. When the water droplets or ice crystals in clouds combine and get heavy enough, gravity pulls them down as precipitation. There are several types of precipitation. Rain is liquid water falling when the temperature is above freezing. Snow forms when water vapor in clouds freezes directly into ice crystals that stick together as snowflakes — every snowflake has a unique shape! Sleet is rain that freezes into small ice pellets as it falls through a layer of cold air near the ground. Hail forms inside tall storm clouds when water droplets are carried up by strong winds and freeze, then fall, get carried up again, freeze more, and eventually get heavy enough to fall to the ground as balls of ice. Most of the precipitation that falls on land flows into streams, rivers, and eventually back to the ocean, where the water cycle starts all over again.

examples.problem: What is the difference between rain and snow?
examples.answer: Rain is liquid water that falls when temperatures are above freezing. Snow is ice crystals that form and fall when temperatures are at or below freezing.
examples.explanation: The temperature of the air determines whether precipitation falls as rain (above 32°F/0°C) or snow (at or below 32°F/0°C).

examples.problem: How does hail form?
examples.answer: Water droplets in tall storm clouds get carried up by strong winds and freeze. They fall, get carried up again, freeze more layers of ice, and get bigger until they are heavy enough to fall to the ground.
examples.explanation: Hailstones can be as small as peas or as large as golf balls! The stronger the wind inside the storm cloud, the larger the hailstones can grow.

content.real_world: Different parts of the world get different types of precipitation. Tropical areas near the equator get mostly rain. Cold regions near the poles get mostly snow. Some places, like deserts, get very little precipitation at all.

content.explanation: After precipitation falls, the water needs to go somewhere — this is called collection. Water collects in many places. Some water flows over the land surface into streams, rivers, lakes, and eventually the ocean. This is called runoff. Some water soaks into the ground and becomes groundwater, which fills the spaces between rocks and soil underground. Plants absorb groundwater through their roots and release it back into the air through transpiration. Some water collects in lakes and ponds. The largest collection of water is in the oceans, which hold about 97% of all water on Earth. Once collected, the water cycle starts again — the sun heats the water, it evaporates, rises to form clouds, and falls again as precipitation. This cycle never stops and is essential for all life on Earth. Without the water cycle, there would be no fresh water for plants, animals, and people to drink.

examples.answer: Some flows over the ground (runoff) into rivers and lakes. Some soaks into the ground (groundwater). Some is absorbed by plants.
examples.explanation: Water takes many different paths after falling as precipitation, but eventually most of it makes its way back to the ocean.

units.title: Simple Machines
units.description: Learn about the six simple machines that help us do work by making it easier to push, pull, or lift things.

content.explanation: A simple machine is a basic device that makes work easier. In science, 'work' means using a force to move something over a distance. Simple machines do not have engines or batteries — they work by changing the direction or amount of force needed to do a job. For example, it is much easier to push a heavy box up a ramp than to lift it straight up. The ramp is a simple machine! There are six types of simple machines: lever, inclined plane (ramp), wheel and axle, pulley, wedge, and screw. These six simple machines are the building blocks of all complex machines. A bicycle, for example, uses wheels and axles, levers (handbrakes and pedals), and pulleys (chain and gears). Simple machines were invented thousands of years ago and are still used every day.

examples.problem: Why is it easier to push a wheelchair up a ramp than to lift it up stairs?
examples.answer: A ramp (inclined plane) spreads the work over a longer distance, so you need less force. Lifting straight up requires more force over a shorter distance.
examples.explanation: Simple machines trade distance for force — you push over a longer distance but with less effort.

examples.problem: Name the six simple machines.
examples.answer: Lever, inclined plane, wheel and axle, pulley, wedge, and screw.
examples.explanation: Every complex machine is made up of combinations of these six basic simple machines.

content.real_world: You use simple machines every day without even thinking about it! Scissors are two levers and two wedges. A doorknob is a wheel and axle. Stairs are inclined planes.

practice_problems.question: What does a simple machine do?

content.explanation: A lever is a bar that rests on a support point called a fulcrum. When you push down on one side of the lever, the other side goes up. Levers make it easier to lift heavy things. A seesaw on a playground is a lever — the center is the fulcrum, and when one side goes down, the other goes up. Other examples of levers include a crowbar, a bottle opener, and even your arm (your elbow is the fulcrum!). An inclined plane is a flat surface that is tilted at an angle — basically a ramp. Inclined planes make it easier to move things up or down. Instead of lifting a heavy box straight up to a truck, you can push it up a ramp using less force over a longer distance. Other examples of inclined planes include stairs, slides, and ramps for wheelchairs.

examples.problem: How does a seesaw work as a lever?
examples.answer: The center of the seesaw is the fulcrum. When one person pushes down on their side, the force lifts the other person up on the other side.
examples.explanation: The lever changes the direction of force — pushing down on one end makes the other end go up.

examples.problem: Why do buildings have ramps?
examples.answer: Ramps (inclined planes) make it easier for people in wheelchairs, with strollers, or carrying heavy loads to move between different levels without lifting.
examples.explanation: A ramp lets you travel a longer distance with less effort, instead of lifting straight up.

content.real_world: When you use a claw hammer to pull out a nail, you are using a lever! The head of the hammer is the fulcrum, and when you pull the handle, the claw lifts the nail out.

content.explanation: A wheel and axle is a simple machine made of a large wheel attached to a smaller rod called an axle. When the wheel turns, the axle turns too (or vice versa). This simple machine makes it much easier to move things. Imagine trying to move a heavy cart without wheels — you would have to drag it! With wheels, the cart rolls easily. Other examples of wheel and axle include doorknobs, steering wheels, screwdrivers, and bicycle wheels. A pulley is a wheel with a groove around its edge and a rope or chain that fits in the groove. When you pull down on one end of the rope, the other end goes up. Pulleys are great for lifting heavy things. A simple pulley changes the direction of force — instead of pushing up, you pull down, which is easier because gravity helps you. Cranes use multiple pulleys together to lift very heavy loads like steel beams.

examples.problem: How does a doorknob use the wheel and axle?
examples.answer: The doorknob is the wheel that you turn. It is attached to a smaller axle that goes through the door and turns the latch.
examples.explanation: Turning the large knob (wheel) makes the small axle turn with more force, which opens the latch.

examples.problem: How does a flagpole pulley work?
examples.answer: A rope goes over a pulley at the top of the flagpole. When you pull down on one end of the rope, the flag goes up on the other end.
examples.explanation: The pulley changes the direction of your force — you pull DOWN and the flag goes UP.

content.real_world: Elevators use pulleys! Strong cables run over pulleys to lift the elevator car up and lower it down in tall buildings.

content.explanation: A wedge is a simple machine with one thick end and one thin, sharp end. When you push the thin end of a wedge into something, it splits the thing apart or pushes it to the side. An axe is a wedge — when you swing it into a log, the thin edge goes in first and forces the wood apart. Knives, chisels, nails, and even your front teeth are wedges! A doorstop is a wedge that you push under a door to hold it open. A screw is actually an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder (like a pole). If you unwound the threads of a screw, they would form a ramp. Screws convert a turning force into a pushing or pulling force. When you turn a screw, it moves deeper into the material, holding things together very tightly. Examples of screws include jar lids, light bulbs (which twist in), and bolts.

examples.problem: How is a knife a wedge?
examples.answer: A knife has a thin, sharp edge (the blade) that pushes into food and splits it apart when you cut.
examples.explanation: The wedge shape concentrates your force on a very thin edge, making it easier to split or cut through materials.

examples.problem: How is a screw related to an inclined plane?
examples.answer: A screw is an inclined plane (ramp) wrapped around a cylinder. The threads of a screw are like a tiny spiral ramp.
examples.explanation: If you cut a triangle from paper (representing an inclined plane) and wrapped it around a pencil, you would see it looks just like screw threads!

content.real_world: Zippers use tiny wedges! The slider has a small wedge inside that either pushes the teeth apart (to open) or pushes them together (to close) as you slide it.

content.explanation: Simple machines are everywhere! Most complex machines and tools are made up of two or more simple machines working together. These combinations are called compound machines. Scissors are a compound machine made of two levers and two wedges. A wheelbarrow combines a lever (the handles), a wheel and axle, and an inclined plane (the tilted bucket). A bicycle uses wheel and axle (the wheels), levers (brakes, pedals), pulleys (chain and gears), and screws (bolts holding it together). Even something as simple as a broom is a lever — your top hand is the fulcrum, and the sweeping end is moved by pushing with your bottom hand. Understanding simple machines helps engineers and inventors design better tools. When you look at any machine, try to identify which simple machines are part of it!

examples.explanation: The handles act as levers with the screw in the middle as the fulcrum, and the blades are wedges that cut through paper.

examples.answer: A wheel and axle (the front wheel), a lever (the handles), and an inclined plane (the tilted bucket).
examples.explanation: Multiple simple machines work together to make the wheelbarrow much easier to use than carrying heavy loads by hand.

content.real_world: Engineers use their knowledge of simple machines to design everything from can openers to roller coasters. Next time you use a tool, see if you can figure out which simple machines are in it!

units.title: Weather & Climate
units.description: Learn about different types of weather, how to measure and predict weather, and the difference between weather and climate.

content.explanation: Weather is the condition of the atmosphere (the air around us) at a specific place and time. Weather includes temperature (how hot or cold it is), precipitation (rain, snow, sleet, or hail), wind (how fast and which direction the air is moving), humidity (how much moisture is in the air), and cloud cover (how many clouds are in the sky). Weather can change from hour to hour and day to day. It might be sunny in the morning and rainy in the afternoon. Weather is different from climate — weather is what is happening right now or today, while climate is the average weather pattern over a long period of time (usually 30 years or more). Scientists who study and predict weather are called meteorologists. They use special tools and technology to help forecast what the weather will be.

examples.problem: What is the difference between weather and climate?
examples.answer: Weather is the short-term condition of the atmosphere (today, this week). Climate is the average weather pattern in an area over a long period of time (decades).
examples.explanation: Think of it this way: weather is what you wear today, climate is what clothes are in your closet for the whole year.

examples.problem: Name five parts of weather.
examples.answer: Temperature, precipitation, wind, humidity, and cloud cover.
examples.explanation: All of these factors together describe the weather conditions at any given time and place.

content.real_world: Meteorologists on TV use radar, satellites, and computer models to predict the weather. Checking the weather forecast helps you decide what to wear and whether to bring an umbrella!

content.explanation: Meteorologists use special tools to measure different parts of the weather. A thermometer measures temperature — how hot or cold the air is. Temperature is measured in degrees Fahrenheit (°F) or degrees Celsius (°C). A rain gauge collects and measures how much rain has fallen. It is basically a container with measurement marks on the side. An anemometer measures wind speed. It has small cups that spin when the wind blows — the faster they spin, the stronger the wind. A wind vane (also called a weather vane) shows the direction the wind is blowing from. A barometer measures air pressure — the weight of the air pushing down on us. Falling air pressure often means a storm is coming, while rising air pressure usually means fair weather. A hygrometer measures humidity (moisture in the air).

examples.answer: A barometer measures air pressure. Low pressure often means stormy weather is coming, and high pressure usually means clear, fair weather.
examples.explanation: Air has weight and pushes down on us. When the pressure drops, it often means a storm system is moving in.

content.real_world: You can make your own rain gauge at home using a clear plastic bottle with measurement marks! Set it outside during a rainstorm and measure how much rain falls.

content.explanation: There are many different types of weather. Sunny weather means clear skies with lots of sunlight. Cloudy weather means the sky is covered with clouds, blocking some or all of the sun. Rainy weather brings precipitation as liquid water falling from clouds. Snowy weather occurs when temperatures are cold enough for precipitation to fall as snowflakes. Windy weather means the air is moving quickly — sometimes gently as a breeze, sometimes strongly as a gust. Foggy weather happens when clouds form very close to the ground, making it hard to see far. Stormy weather can include thunderstorms (with lightning, thunder, heavy rain, and sometimes hail), blizzards (heavy snow with strong winds), and tornadoes (violently spinning columns of air). Severe weather like hurricanes, tornadoes, and blizzards can be dangerous and people need to take shelter to stay safe.

examples.problem: What causes thunder?
examples.answer: Lightning heats the air around it to incredibly high temperatures. The superheated air expands so quickly that it creates a shockwave — that is the sound of thunder!
examples.explanation: Light travels faster than sound, so you see lightning before you hear thunder. You can estimate how far away a storm is by counting seconds between lightning and thunder — about 5 seconds equals one mile.

examples.problem: What is a blizzard?
examples.answer: A blizzard is a severe winter storm with heavy snowfall, strong winds (at least 35 mph), and low visibility that lasts at least three hours.
examples.explanation: Blizzards can make it very dangerous to drive or be outside because you cannot see and the cold can cause frostbite.

content.real_world: Weather forecasts help communities prepare for severe weather. Schools practice tornado drills and hurricane evacuations so everyone knows what to do when dangerous weather is on the way.

content.explanation: While weather changes day to day, climate is the average pattern of weather in a region over a long period (usually 30 years or more). Different places on Earth have different climates. Tropical climates near the equator are hot and wet all year. Polar climates near the North and South Poles are cold all year. Temperate climates (like most of the United States) have four seasons: spring, summer, fall, and winter. Seasons happen because Earth is tilted on its axis as it orbits the sun. When the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the sun, it gets more direct sunlight and has summer. When it is tilted away from the sun, it gets less direct sunlight and has winter. Deserts have a hot, dry climate with very little rainfall. Rainforests have a warm, wet climate with lots of rain. The type of climate an area has determines what plants and animals can live there.

examples.problem: Why do we have seasons?
examples.answer: Earth is tilted on its axis. As Earth orbits the sun, different parts of the planet are tilted toward or away from the sun, receiving more or less direct sunlight.
examples.explanation: When your hemisphere is tilted toward the sun, you get more direct sunlight and warmer weather (summer). When tilted away, you get less and have winter.

examples.problem: What is the difference between weather and climate?
examples.answer: Weather is what is happening outside right now (today's temperature, rain, wind). Climate is the average weather pattern in an area over many years.
examples.explanation: A city might have rainy weather today, but its climate overall might be dry if it rarely rains throughout the year.

content.real_world: When packing for a vacation, you check the climate of your destination (is it usually hot or cold there?) and the weather forecast (will it rain while you are visiting?).
